author: @Dont-Ask-Me-My-Name
text: I loved the OG film from 1984 but I haven't seen Dune Part 1 yet.  I was waiting for Dune Part 2 to come out &I am absolutely going to watch Part 1 &then hit the I-Max for Part 2.  After Kill Bill vol 2 I told myself never again am I doing this Part 1 and then Part 2 not when it's the plan from the beginning nope.  Glad everyone that I watch/listen to is saying that the film is great &I absolutely agree that Greig Fraser is the best cinematographer in the business.  In my mind he's fighting with the great Wally Pfister for best cinematographer of the last 40 years w/ Nolan's new guy the only other one that is even in the conversation

Should I watch it? I have held off on watching part 1 until part 2 came out. So I'm looking at around 8 hours of movie watching, with drink runs and bathroom breaks. Which is fine, but ... author: @Lanceawright
text:
Before you were around, they did a Dune in the 1980s... I was in the theater opening night, and they were handing out pamphlets explaining things about the movie's story BEFORE we were to watch the movie.

If you need to add Cliff's Notes BEFORE you tell the story via the cinematic medium, you have failed as a story teller.

This one does much better.

author: @Pengalen
text:
Having watched Dune Part 1, though the cinematography is sometimes nice in a very retro-futuristic way, like it would be cool in a series of stills in a coffee-table book, the whole movie is kind of dry and bland compared to the one from the 80's, which was stylish and vigorous by comparison. Also Chalomet is kind of annoying compared to Kyle MachLachlan.
Vaguely related, Edna Mode has to be based off of Linda Hunt, who played Shadout Mapes, and omg, I didn't know that Si√¢n Phillips was also Cassiopeia in Clash of the Titans, but it makes perfect sense now.
